docs.lead_paragraph: When he died, sometime after noon on a Friday last August, a nurse gently folded the tiny body of Adam Herrera inside a white blanket and handed the baby to his father. ''You know,'' says Art Herrera, who still cannot recall the moment without tears, ''it was the first time we held our son when he wasn't hooked up with wires and tubes to some machine.'' For the next 15 minutes, Mr. Herrera and his wife, Jan, sat with the body of their 11-week-old son, alone in a special room alongside the busy neonatal intensive care unit at Denver's Children's Hospital. ''When I think back on that day, even now I don't remember the ugly parts as much as I do that special time we had alone with Adam,'' said Mrs. Herrera, who, like her husband, is a schoolteacher in northern Colorado. ''Otherwise we would never have been able to hold him and stroke him like that.''

byline.original: By WILLIAM E. SCHMIDT, Special to the New York Times

docs.lead_paragraph: A new study says a ''baby-sitting'' requirement at many hospitals is costing the state more than $1 million a year and may be discouraging timely medical treatment for patients from New York State mental institutions. The study, by the State Commission on the Quality of Care for the Mentally Disabled, found that hospitals in the state often require, through written agreement or tradition, that psychiatric institutions provide either a therapy aide or registered nurse during hospital stays for their residents. This rule, the study says, costs the state $1.2 million a year, or the equivalent of the annual salary of 93 therapy aides, as well as overtime costs and disruptions at the mental hospitals. Clarence Sundram, chairman of the commission, said that these workers simply ''baby sit'' for the mentally disabled during their hospital stays and are not allowed to provide any medical treatment.
